results.title: Age of terror
results.brief_description: Comprehensive and well-researched documentary about the history of terrorism tracing it from to the 1940s, to the present day. Using archival footage, and a slew of enlightening interviews the filmmakers address the methodologies, ideologies and outcomes of terrorism, tackling an array of worldwide historical events. “In the name of liberation” This segment covers the wars fought, over the decades, in the name of liberating homelands. Topics covered include the conflict in Palestine, the war in Algiers against the French, the Malay versus the British, the South African conflict and the ANC, and the bombings in Ireland. “In the name of the revolution” Examines guerrilla warfare of the 20th century and clashes in Cuba, Peru, Italy and Germany in the name of revolution. Key players in these conflicts are interviewed, explaining their motivations at the time, with many reflecting upon what those outcomes mean to them now. “In the name of God” Examines acts of terrorism committed in the name of religion. Conflicts covered include the 1970 hijacking of several airplanes, in order to draw attention to Palestine - regarded as the world’s first media terrorist event. Topics covered include: September 11, suicide bombers, Osama Bin Laden, the 1997 terrorism attack in Egypt, Islam, Al Qaeda, Jihad, Zionism, issues in the Middle East and Palestine, conflicts in the Arab world, battles between Jews and Muslims, and militant groups that dominate terrorism. “In the name of the state” Examines the issues of state sponsored terror. What happens when governments commit acts of terrorism and torture against their own people? Looks at the situation in Argentina in the 1970s, when state sanctioned terror saw the disappearance and torture of innumerable citizens, many of whom were never seen again. One interviewee, a survivor of torture describes how pregnant women were made to give birth under captivity only for the babies to be given to military families. Also looks at Iranian state sponsored terrorism.

results.title: Ageing
results.brief_description: This informative video looks at the physical aspects of growing old and explores some of the mysteries of ageing. It looks at the correlation between age and activity and shows that people who treat their bodies with respect can be as active and energetic as people half their age.

results.title: Afterlife
results.creator_credit: Ishu Patel, Derek Lamb and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: What is dying? How does it feel? Afterlife is an impressionistic and visionary response to these eternal questions. Based on recent studies, case histories, and some of the ancient myths, the afterlife state is portrayed as an awesome but methodical working-out of all the individual’s past experiences. Music performed by Herbie Mann. Nine awards including Montreal, Chicago, Hong Kong, Annecy and Columbus.

results.title: After the Warming
results.creator_credit: Mike Slee, Richard Sattin and Film Australia
results.brief_description: It is the year 2050. Mankind and the earth have survived global warming. In an innovative new television project, social journalist James Burke looks back from the future of several scenarios of global warming and their possible effects on continents, countries and mankind. He explores the preventative roads not taken and the potential results.

results.title: After the Montreal massacre
results.creator_credit: Gerry Rogers, Nicole Hubert, Canadian Broadcasting Corporation and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: In 1989 Marc Lepine shot and killed 14 women students. As he opened fire he yelled “You’re all a bunch of feminists”. This program is a useful tool not only in analysing this femicide, but throws light on what has become an increasing trend of male violence against women. Sylvie Gagnon, a survivor of the massacre, and other Canadian women talk of their fears, the influence of the media and social conditions, the Women’s Movement and the need to be empowered. The pervasive thread underlying their narrative is that violence towards women is not a solitary act committed by a disturbed personality, but instilled into the cultural and social fabric of society as one of the most pervasive yet least recognised violations of Human Rights. The haunting images taken on the day of the massacre and in the days following, are terrifying and moving, challenging us to explore the urgent issues of misogyny, male violence and sexism.

results.title: After Mr. Sam
results.creator_credit: Arthur Hammond and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A documentary record of a three-day conference held in Steinberg Limited’s lodge north of Montreal. Here, faced with the stepping down of Sam Steinberg as president, ambitious top-level executives thrash out their differences in matters of corporation policy and objectives, ever aware of the crucial issue: who will be president after Mr. Sam? Sprinkled with Sam Steinberg’s reminiscences and reflections on business, full of insights into the workings of a large corporation and clashes of interest and character, the film presents an unusually close view of a struggle for power and position.

results.title: Afrika: Cape Town to Cairo
results.creator_credit: Michael Davie, Ellenor Cox, Marcul Gillezeau and Firelight Productions
results.brief_description: A four part series presented by Michael Davie, a 22-year-old writer and filmmaker who set out to travel from one side of Africa to the other, the notorious 8500km journey from Cape Town to Cairo through dangerous and spectacular surroundings including Johannesburg, Zimbabwe, Mozambique, Lake Malawi, Mount Kilimanjaro and Ethiopia. Arrested, beaten and interrogated numerous times on his journey, Michael reached his destination seven months after starting. The parts of the series are: Episode 1: Warriors and Witchdoctors - Michael begins by rediscovering his roots, having left the country as a childhood refugee, before travelling to Johannesburg where he meets Geraldine, a homeless prostitute and discovers the city’s violence firsthand. Episode 2: Home is Where the Landmines Are - Michael hitches to Zimbabwe and is arrested for investigating the lives of street kids before heading to Mozambique where he meets a 5 year old landmine victim and watches her learn to walk again. Episode 3: Slobs in Paradise - Michael travels Lake Malawi and Dar es Salam, investigates the heroin trade in Tanzania and climbs Mount Kilimanjaro. Episode 4: Delinquents, Tribes and Millionaires - Michael searches for the Masai warriors and meets some teenage millionaires in Kenya before sailing up the Nile to Cairo.

results.title: African city: contrasting cultures
results.creator_credit: Frank Gardonyi, Clifford Janoff and Bailey Film Productions
results.brief_description: Discusses the great contrasts of culture, life style and economic well being in the African city of Abidjan on the Ivory Coast. Shows the two distinct areas which represent the dichotomy between the poor and the wealthy.

results.title: Africa alive
results.brief_description: Africa is a continent of mystery and beauty known for the splendour and grandeur of its wildlife which is under threat by poachers decimating the continent’s elephant and rhinoceros populations. “Africa Alive” reveals modern Africa in all its guises; its timeless beauty and its many characters. The expedition travels coastal Africa in a traditional vessel to capture the the soul and spirit of this distinctive land.

results.title: Africa : village on stilts
results.creator_credit: Denis Hargrave, Canadian Broadcasting Corporation and UNICEF
results.brief_description: Depicts the tribal traditions in a typical fishing village in the Republic of Dahomey, Africa, where the houses are built high on stilts above the water. Features Nicolas an 11 year old boy, as he goes to school, swims, plays and helps his father. Also shows how the piping in of clean drinking water helped reduce the death rate from cholera and other water-borne diseases. Narrated by Percy Rodriguez.
